notes_fields.Macro: Retrieved from a flower pot at an apartment complex in Beeville, Texas. Overall color was sulfur yellow and no color change was noted from bruising or application of KOH, NH4OH, or FeSo4. Cap with an unbo and free gills was 6cm across (circular) stipe was 8cm long. The base of stipe was bulbous (12mm) lessoning to 4mm at top. Stipe was hollow with a string present in the hollow.
notes_fields.Micro: Even though the spores were collected from a white spore print, there seemed to be a large variation in size. I measured one example was about the average size to be 9.3µm x 6.3µm.
notes_fields.Soil_Type: Since this mushroom was growing in a flower pot, I have not included a soil type description.

results.notes:
Recomendaciones para su registro, descripción y posterior determinación:
-Fotografiar estructuras del basidioma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada.
-Es importante que describas las dimensiones, forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona (sustrato) para hacer un seguimiento y logres detallar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero)
-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, etc).
-No olvides que la determinación de hongos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de genero y especie; en la mayoría) implica otras actividades como descripción morfológica externa e interna, reacciones químicas, microscopia y ADN.

otras recomendaciones en:
Grupo XYLARIA Hongos de Colombia ©2015

INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/neotropical_fungi/

results.notes:
Registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017). Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Recomendaciones para su registro, descripción y posterior determinación:
-Fotografiar estructuras del basidioma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada.
-Es importante que describas las dimensiones, forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona (sustrato) para hacer un seguimiento y logres detallar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero)
-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, etc).
-No olvides que la determinación de hongos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de genero y especie; en la mayoría) implica otras actividades como descripción morfológica externa e interna, reacciones químicas, microscopia y ADN.

results.notes:
I found about a dozen fruiting solitary but in the same general area and habitat (from clay soil on the side of the trail). They all appear to be the same species, I believe few got a chance to fully develop with the weird weather patterns we have had recently, so many buttons were dry with an unexpanded cap. The passing of tropical storm Isaías dumped several inches of rain on El Yunque, but immediately afterwards dry conditions returned and the forest remains in drought worsened by the fact that the storm ripped open new holes in the canopy which allows the sun to dry up the understory.
Spores about 6-7 um, rarely exceeding 7. Setaceous hyphae present at the base of the stipe. Cheilocystidia is very heteromorphous, and I saw many forms and shapes that are not illustrated in the literature (see drawing). I looked at two individuals and they did not have pigmented cystidia, which all look consistently hyaline. This trait seems to vary according to a collection made around 2018 which I scoped with Jean Lodged and we found individuals with and without pigmented cystidia that otherwise agreed in all other traits observed. The publication ‘New Species of Psilocybe in the Caribbean’ (2003) also mentions that a collection from the Dominican Republic “lacks the yellowish or grayish opaque pleurocystidia and the brownish or grayish opaque cheilocystidia that are typical of P. guilartensis” but that “the presence of the highly distinctive setaceous hyphae at the base of the stipe indicates this collection has strong phenotypic affinities with P. guilartensis” and that “the lack of pigments…might be due to the immaturity of the specimens”. This seems to be consistent with discussions I’ve had with Alan Rockefeller of the related taxa ‘P. heimii’ and ‘P. banderillensis’ which may be conspecific but are designated based on presence or absence of pigmented cystidia.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 150270663 on March 4, 2023.

Leccinum insigne
08062020
Hubachek Wilderness Research Center (Ely, MN)

- Ecology: In mixed woods, heavily conifer. Was found in middle of trail growing from dried liverwort/lichen.
- Cap: 60 mm. Convex. Light brown/brownsh-gray. Smooth, but slightly cracked appearance from direct sun. Flesh=creme/off-white but dying violet.
- Pore surface: Slight depression where pores meet stem. Cream/off-white/tan (bruising darker). 2-3 pores per mm.
- Stem: Off white/tan. With black scabbers. 40 mm width. 25 mm width.
- Spore print: bown with hint of yellow.

results.notes:
Up to 10 fruitbodies growing in short grass/moss under old red oaks.
Overall, this species resembles T. variobrunneus, and, indeed, a single specimen collected from this spot on 5-Aug-20 (to be posted later) supports this notion, but some salient morphological features of the present collection suggest it could be a different taxon. For example, the cap surface closer to the margins is heavily covered in dense clusters of tufts of erect fibrils or scabers, giving it a wrinkled appearance. The stipes feature a fine, but obvious, elongated netting that transitions into an almost smooth surface sprinkled with small brown spots and smears intermixed with some scruffiness. Another interesting feature was revealed upon sectioning: the flesh right under the pileipellis eventually stained grayish-green in older specimens. Upon further examination, when peeled, the undersurface of the thick cuticle (up to 1 mm thick) and the surface of the flesh immediately below the cuticle were found to be yellow.
The largest caps (fruitbodies 1 & 2) had a 10-11 cm footprint, with a flesh thickness above the stipe of 2.5-2.7 cm. The tube layer in these two basidiomata was 7-10 mm deep. The short & stout stipes were 5-6 cm long, 2.4-2.7 cm wide at the apex, narrowing to 1.5-1.6 cm; the stipe of #1, however, widened to 2cm at the base, while the other one narrowed to a pinched base. I have recorded the measurements of the other 5 fruitbodies, but feel it unnecessary to list them here.
The odor was pleasant and the flesh was mild-tasting. All 7 basidomata were preserved and bagged separately.

Teodoro Chivatá, Hongos lignícolas de Yopal Casanare, 2020

Recomendaciones para su registro, descripción y posterior determinación:
-Fotografiar estructuras del basidioma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada.
-Es importante que describas las dimensiones, forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona (sustrato) para hacer un seguimiento y logres detallar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero)
-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, entre otros).
-No olvides que la determinación de hongos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de genero y especie; en la mayoría) implica otras actividades como descripción morfológica externa e interna, reacciones químicas, microscopia y ADN.

results.notes:
A single specimen growing in short grass/moss under old oaks. Upon arriving home, I found the cap fully expanded and that the mushroom grew taller. Here are the final fruitbody measurements:
Cap = 5.2 × 5.6 cm footprint; striations 1.1-1.4 cm long, generally 1.2 cm long (up to 0.43R); flesh 5 mm thick above the stipe

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 3-Jun-21):
> This collection was sampled for nrITS by Dr. Kudzma. The derived nrDNA sequence of 530 base pairs (bps) consists of the full-length nrITS locus of 489 characters capped with short adjoining nrSSU and nrLSU fragments on the 5’ and 3’ termini, respectively.
> The posted sequence is a “joined contig” because of heterogeneity at the very end of the ITS2 region (that’s where the two reads are stitched together). As a matter of fact, the locus is interspersed with substantial “on-and-off heterogeneity” and scattered ambiguities. Some of this heterogeneity in ITS1 consisting of two overlapping haplotypes was successfully resolved, but the reported sequence is still messy, as a total of 31 positions cannot be confidently assigned. The bulk of the sequence save the last 30 characters in ITS2 comes from the forward read that required a lot diligent work to get the most out of it. The reverse read is in much worse shape — once the heterogeneity sets in, the rest of the trace becomes totally useless.
> These problems notwithstanding, the handicapped barcode gene does give 10 accessions of Amanita justicei and 2 accessons of A. scutum by Rod Tulloss as top hits in GenBank when a 491 bps sequence fragment containing only 13 ambiguous positions is used as a query in the BLASTn tool. Alignment of these sequences are shown in Fig. 1. As can be seen, heterogeneity in nrITS is a common problem in A. justicei, resulting in four partial sequences and plentiful ambiguous content in some accessions. The sequences of A. scutum are very close to those of A. justicei, with ITS1 providing better resolution between the two taxa and ITS2 instead having what looks like hybridized content. According to RET, A. scutum morphologically resembles A. jakeslandensis with its dark and zonate cap, while the cap of A. justicei is “tan or yellowish tan becoming sordid yellow-brown over disc and over marginal striations, with lighter (less brown) intervening zone yellowish to yellow cream, becoming pale olive tan”. It remains to be seen whether the two taxa can be more reliably discerned by protein-coding genes.
Identification of MO421190 as Amanita justicei makes good sense on the grounds of gross-morphology and genetic data.

results.notes:
Recomendaciones para su registro, descripción y posterior determinación:
-Fotografiar estructuras del basidioma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada.
-Es importante que describas las dimensiones, forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona (sustrato) para hacer un seguimiento y logres detallar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero)
-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, entre otros).
-No olvides que la determinación de hongos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de genero y especie; en la mayoría) implica otras actividades como descripción morfológica externa e interna, reacciones químicas, microscopia y ADN.

results.notes:
Field notes:
orla de pinhal, entre estêvas e outras rasteiras
cheiro: espermático
pileus: mais amarelado, por vezes alaranjado ou até acastanhado. Algo rimoso.
stipe: liso, não pruinoso, creme a amarelo claro, base bulbosa
laminae: cremes a castanhas claras.

Microscopy notes:
-himenial cystidia thick walls which seem somewhat reactive to ammonia, hard to see under 100x, 40x shows better. Sometimes coallescing, many times not.
-pleurocystidia are abundant! they are heavy on crystals, which seem to extend to lower parts of cystidia often forming a collar of smaller specs around the neck or even into lower cystidia parts (like I. castanea!?). Short or no pedicel
-cheilocystidia are often like pleurocystidia, but many times blukier and without neck or pedicel (then with different crystal pattern).
-stipe apex (1/4) with abundant well spread pluri shaped caulocystidia, some like himenial cystidia but many are short, bottle-shaped, some rather fusiform with short nipple, also often more twisted. Some with pedicel.
- middle stipe (2/3) with caulocystidia like stipe apex, just not as abundant, still plenty spread all over
-low stipe 3/4 like above
-basal stipe (4/4) no caulocystidia were found.
-Spores variable in size and Q-value, but with heterodiametrical tendency imo (few isodiametrical found):
(7.1) 7.7 – 9.1 (10.3) × (4.4) 5 – 6.7 (7) µm
Q = (1.1) 1.3 – 1.6 (2) ; N = 70
Me = 8.4 × 5.8 µm ; Qe = 1.5
knobs: Me ~1.5 um

A single specimen growing in short grass/moss under old oaks. It occurred to me later in the day, when I was taking fruitbody measurements at home, that this might be an example of A. onusta whose volva on cap was washed away by rain. However, now, when I have an LSU sequence, this clearly not the case, as it doesn’t match RET’s accession of onusta, HQ539718. Obs 328626, found at this location but not exactly the same spot in 2018, is possibly the same species.
Overall height = 13-13.5 cm. Cap = 6 cm wide footprint; flesh = 6 mm thick above stipe. Gill = 4-5 mm wide. Stipe = 12.5-13 cm long, 1 cm wide at the flaring apex, 7 mm wide at its narrowest point (2 cm below apex), gradually widening to 1 cm just above the bulb. Bulb = 3.5 cm long, 1.3 cm wide max.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 30-Mar-23):
This collection was sampled for LSU by Dr. Kudzma. The locus was amplified using LSU0F and LR7 primers. The 1397 bps sequence obtained from this amplicon is a joined contig of two forward reads, LSU0F & LR3R. The latter read reaches all the way to the LR7 primer area, which was seen and edited out. The two reads have a common overlap of 358 characters. There are a total of 7 ambiguities scattered about the sequence: six Y (C/T) and one R (A/G). The sequence has been uploaded to this post.
A BLASTn search of the first 915 bps of this sequence, which constitute the most commonly sequenced region of LSU (through to LR5 primer area), produced hits that are only 93% similar at the most, meaning that this critter is only distantly related to other Lepidellas. Based on this result and the overall morphology, it follows that this is most likely an undescribed taxon.

This collection was submitted to Dr. Kudzma for sequencing (ITS).
DNA sequencing results and discussion (posted 19-Jun-22; edited on 20-Jun-22):
ITS failed to homogenize in this organism, producing two sequence variants, one of which is longer than the other by one base, which is a common occurrence in this locus. Other than that the two sequences are identical. The point of heterogeneity is in located in late ITS2 region, 48 bases away from LSU (see Fig.1).
In the presence of a single point of heterogeneity, full-length sequences are usually obtained by stitching the two reads at the point of sequence “derailment”, also provided that the reads are clean and show SSU & LSU regions where aplicon/sequencing primers originate. However, here noise obscures the 5’ and 3’ ends of the sequence in the forward and reverse reads, respectively. That said, while the forward read delivers the bulk of sequence, the 3’ end of it had to be resolved all the way to ITS6R primer to get the late ITS2 and the adjacent LSU fragment. To get the left hand side of the sequence (SSU fragment and early ITS1), the reverse read had to be worked on to resolve the two haplotypes. When the dust settled, I had the entire sequence between the amplicon primers, and 63% of it was supported by both reads (the consensus portion). The longer haplotype was chosen for reporting because there was more of it (area under the curve).

I took some photos of mushrooms while backpacking after a few days of heavy rain through a predominantly pine, oak, birch forest.

I did not touch any of them or even get good underneath shots but I was hoping the community could help me narrow down an ID for some of them.

The mushroom in question here is the pink one. I am 99% sure that I looked underneath and saw that it looked like a bolete. Also there were many other boletes fruiting at this time in the area.

I have no idea if the other larger mushrooms pictured are related to this one, they look like a different type of mushroom to me

I plan on posting a second observation of another pink bolete that was growing within 1000m of this one that I suspect is the same species.
